docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG - "It took one second to ruin my life completely,'' the scarred woman says. "My face was ruined and nobody was punished at all.''
docs.abstract: "It took one second to ruin my life completely,'' the scarred woman says. "My face was ruined and nobody was punished at all.'' That chilling remark - from a Pakistani woman who was attacked with acid - is from the film "Saving Face," which won the Academy Award for best short documentary.

headline.main: 'It Took One Second to Ruin My Life'

docs.snippet: 9 P.M. (13, 49) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: RED, WHITE AND BLUES President and Mrs. Obama host a celebration of the blues in the East Room of the White House, including songs by John Lee Hooker and Muddy Waters, performed by Troy Andrews, J...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: RED, WHITE AND BLUES President and Mrs. Obama host a celebration of the blues in the East Room of the White House, including songs by John Lee Hooker and Muddy Waters, performed by Troy Andrews, Jeff Beck, Gary Clark Jr., Shemekia Copeland, Buddy Guy, Warren Haynes, Mick Jagger, B. B. King (above), Keb Mo, Susan Tedeschi and Derek Trucks. Booker T. Jones is the bandleader; Taraji P. Henson hosts. The evening ends with the president serenading the audience with a few bars of ''Sweet Home Chicago.'' ''Blues singing is part oratory, and after a faltering start on Tuesday, Mr. Obama declaimed his lines with adequate warmth and gusto,'' Jon Pareles wrote in The New York Times. ''He also knew enough not to start into an additional verse.'' 6 A.M. (HBO Signature) IT'S KIND OF A FUNNY STORY (2010) Craig (Keir Gilchrist), a teenager plagued by thoughts of suicide, checks himself into a psychiatric hospital after falling for his best friend's girl (Zoë Kravitz) and finding that his well-meaning parents (Lauren Graham and Jim Gaffigan) can't quite give him the support he needs. Enter Bobby (Zach Galifianakis), a soulful, scatterbrained would-be mentor, and Noelle (Emma Roberts), a potential love interest, who both ease Craig's stay while also complicating it. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott called this film, adapted from Ned Vizzini's novel by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck, ''disarmingly gentle, sweet and whimsical,'' even if some of the brazenness and flair of the book had been lost. But, he added, ''the calm, helpful spirit of the film is also threaded with condescension: this is a movie made by grown-ups, who want to listen and help, to make sure that everyone has a good time, and that nobody gets hurt.'' Final analysis: ''The best I can say is that it's kind of a good movie.''

docs.snippet: LOS ANGELES - The writer-director-actor Taika Waititi's vaguely autobiographical movie ''Boy'' charmed the Sundance Film Festival, where it was nominated for a Grand Jury Prize. That was a little more than two years ago.     It was then the toast ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - The writer-director-actor Taika Waititi's vaguely autobiographical movie ''Boy'' charmed the Sundance Film Festival, where it was nominated for a Grand Jury Prize. That was a little more than two years ago. It was then the toast of Berlin, where ''Boy'' won a major festival prize. That was also in 2010.
docs.abstract: Media Decoder blog notes the slow pace of independent film distribution in the United States; points out mvoie Boy will open in New York three years after it was filmed. Photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: “The Artist” won best picture at the Academy Awards, with Jean Dujardin winning best actor for that film and Meryl Streep taking best actress for “The Iron Lady.”
docs.abstract: Winners at the 84th Academy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles include The Artist for best picture, Jean Dujardin for best actor and Meryl Streep for best actress; film Hugo also wins multiple Oscars.

docs.snippet: This year’s Academy Awards ceremony was out with the new, back with the old, and not just because “The Artist,” a largely silent film set in 1920s Hollywood, won so many awards....
docs.lead_paragraph: This year’s Academy Awards ceremony was out with the new, back with the old, and not just because “The Artist,” a largely silent film set in 1920s Hollywood, won so many awards.
docs.abstract: Alessandra Stanley assesses the 84th annual telecast of the Academy Awards ceremony, featuring host Billy Crystal; observes that nostalgia, tradition and a return to the past were the overarching themes that dominated the show.

headline.seo: Billy Crystal’s Shtick, and the Academy, Need Freshening

docs.snippet: This year the fashion offerings seemed spectacularly bland, with even young women apparently compelled to wear long dresses with pools of fabric around their feet....
docs.lead_paragraph: This year the fashion offerings seemed spectacularly bland, with even young women apparently compelled to wear long dresses with pools of fabric around their feet.
docs.abstract: Eric Wilson reviews fashion offerings at the 84th Academy Awards show; notes that many actresses seemed afraid to take a big fashion risk, opting instead to wear long, spectacularly bland gowns.

docs.abstract: West defeats East, 152-149, in the NBA All-Star Game; Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant scores 27 points, surpassing Michael Jordan as the most prolific scorer in the history of the All-Star competition.

headline.seo: West Holds Off the East After Bryant Overtakes Jordan
